review.title: Oriented Straight Line Segment Algebra: Qualitative Spatial Reasoning about Oriented Objects
review.abstract: Nearly 15 years ago, a set of qualitative spatial relations between oriented straight line segments (dipoles) was suggested by Schlieder. This work received substantial interest amongst the qualitative spatial reasoning community. However, it turned out to be difficult to establish a sound constraint calculus based on these relations. In this paper, we present the results of a new investigation into dipole constraint calculi which uses algebraic methods to derive sound results on the composition of relations and other properties of dipole calculi. Our results are based on a condensed semantics of the dipole relations.

sections.heading: 2.1 Basic Representation of Dipole Relations
sections.text: The basic entities we use are dipoles, i.e. oriented line segments formed by a pair of two points, a starting point and an end point. Dipoles are defined by A, B, C,., starting points by sA and end points by eA, respectively (see Figure 1). These dipoles are used to represent spatial objects with an intrinsic orientation. In view of a number of dipoles, it is possible to specify many different relationships in different ways, e.g. depending on the length of the dipoles, on the angle between different dipoles, or on the dimension and nature of the underlying space. In investigating different relationships, the aim is to obtain a set of jointly exhausted and paired disjunctural relationships, so that exactly one relationship exists between any two dipoles. The elements of the basic relationships are called general relations.

sections.heading: 2.2 Several Versions of Sets of Dipole Base Relations
sections.text: It is an unrealistic goal to construct a single set of basic qualitative relations suitable for all possible contexts. In general, the desired granularity of a representational framework depends on the specific application [35]. A rough granularity needs only a small amount of basic relations. A finer granularity can lead to a large number of basic relations. Therefore, when it comes to applying a spatial complexity, it is advantageous if a choice can be made between several versions of basic relations. Then, a calculation can be selected that only has the necessary number of basic relations and therefore less representational complexity, but it is sufficiently fine-grained to solve the respective spatial rationale problem. Focusing the smallest number of basic relations also fits better with the principle of a vocabulary relationship that is compatible with linguistic principles. [15, 14] For this purpose, several basic relations can be constructed.
